title: Would you buy a replica of Shakespeare’s home?
text:
To buy or not to buy, that is the question. This Tudor-style home in the Perth Hills is just one of three replicas of the great William Shakespeare’s original family home.

Built in 1975 by late English engineer Leo Fowler, the property is part of a small Elizabethan village at 25 Canns Road, Bedfordale, which includes a copy of Shakespeare’s wife Anne Hathaway’s cottage, and is based on the Bard’s birthplace in Stratford-upon-Avon.

Fowler moved to Western Australia with his wife, Margaret, in 1974 with grand plans to establish an entire Elizabethan village, including an English restaurant. But it was never completed due to ill health and he sold to a local businessman.

Current owner Tina Alexander, who has lived in the special home for 16 years, says she was attracted to the property because of her love of Tudor homes, but concedes she is not an overt lover of literature.

“I like history and I love bold architecture – things that make a statement. This is not just an ordinary, run-of-the-mill place and that’s what really drew me here,” Alexander says.

“I never really was a Shakespeare fan and I’m not into reading or writing, although I do poetry. But when I moved in I just wanted to know more about what Shakespeare did, so I had all these books and I read up a lot about Shakespeare.”

Set on 1848sqm, the three-storey five-bedroom, five-bathroom home has four living areas, four fireplaces and unique pantry doors in the country kitchen.

“Although the house is big, it still feels homely,” Alexander says.

“It’s great for entertaining because it’s so theatrical. We’ve held so many events – Pirates of the Caribbean, Harry Potter, gothic, medieval, Mad Hatter’s party themed events.”

Built from timber from the old Barrack Street and Busselton jetties, Toodyay stone, clay shingle tiles and leadlight windows sourced from England, the property has been modelled to precision on the original, even mimicking its imperfections and a secret room.

“There is a secret room,” Alexander says. “It’s like a big panel so when you close it it looks like the end of the house, but there is a room behind it. That was for all their valuables and grains – they would store everything of value in that room in England.”

Opened by Sir Charles Court in 1977 as a tourist attraction, it won the 1978 Sir David Brand Award for Tourism and still retains the original ticketing office.

It transitioned to a private residence about 30 years ago.

Alexander, who operated a bed and breakfast from the distinctive residence for years, says her home remains a local icon, with tourists and passersby still stopping to admire it.

“It attracted so many people through the 1970s and 80s as being the most authentic replica of Shakespeare’s house and Anne Hathaway’s next door… I still get people coming through. They are so attracted to the place that in the end I ask them if they want to come in and have a look.”

Alexander has decided to sell so she can invest in a property where she is able to take care of her aging parents.

The property has been listed for sale from $1.05 million to $1.25 million and is being marketed by Aydin Palermo, from Oradin Property Maida Vale.
description: To buy or not to buy, that is the question. This quaint Tudor-style home in the Perth Hills is just one of three replicas of William Shakespeare’s family home in England.
